title: 112_hr2124
content: The Act titled "Southwest Cross-border Violence Recognition Act of 2011" aims to reduce cross-border violence. The "Southwest Cross-border Violence Recognition Act of 2011" requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to submit a report on metrics for measuring cross-border violence within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Periodic reports must be submitted every 90 days thereafter to the relevant congressional committees. The "Southwest Cross-border Violence Recognition Act of 2011" mandates regular reports on cross-border violence incidents, including crime statistics from various sources like border sheriff reports and local hospital data on injuries from such violence. The "Southwest Cross-border Violence Recognition Act of 2011" requires reports on cross-border violence incidents, including impacts on property values and businesses, and accounts of violence reported by U.S. agencies. The term "cross-border violence" refers to any act of violence carried out by individuals from different nationalities or legal statuses. The curr_chunk discusses unlawful activities occurring within 100 miles of the US border that benefit foreign nationals, organizations, or entities involved in organized crime. The curr_chunk discusses violent acts committed by foreign nationals, entities, or organizations targeting unlawful activities near the US border. The curr_chunk defines violence as unlawful acts intentionally or unintentionally inflicted within 100 miles of the US border, including criminal violence and border-related organized crime violence. The curr_chunk outlines different types of violence related to cross-border crime in the United States, including violence against law enforcement agents, border violence within 100 miles of the border, and spillover violence originating in Mexico. The curr_chunk describes violence related to conflicts among Trans-national Criminal Organizations (TCOs) in Mexico that extends into the United States or threatens US interests. It also includes offensive violence by TCOs against US personnel or interests in both countries.
